researchExperience.focus: Solar Radiation Management and Climate Engineering
researchExperience.description: Conducted computational research on stratospheric aerosol interventions as potential climate engineering approaches. Used climate modeling software to simulate and analyze different aerosol types and their cooling effectiveness.
keyFindings: Discovered black carbon aerosols in the stratosphere are approximately 10x more effective at cooling than traditional reflective sulfate aerosols
Analyzed temperature, albedo, and radiative forcing effects across different aerosol compositions
Evaluated implications for climate intervention strategies and geoengineering feasibility
researchExperience.methodology: Computational climate modeling using Python-based tools, data analysis of simulation outputs, quantitative comparison of aerosol effectiveness
researchExperience.impact: Findings challenge conventional assumptions in solar radiation management research and suggest alternative approaches to climate intervention

extracurriculars.involvement: Founded and led Hoverloon project - a hybrid blimp-drone platform that achieved 19x payload capacity improvement through innovative integration of buoyant lift with electric propulsion
extracurriculars.impact: Demonstrated novel approach to aerial robotics combining lighter-than-air technology with quadcopter control systems

technical: Python programming for scientific computing and ML
C++ for robotics and embedded systems
interdisciplinary: Bridging computer science, engineering, and climate science

achievements: Published research presentation on solar radiation management
Founded successful robotics project (Hoverloon) with demonstrated 19x performance improvement
Active contributor to Princeton robotics community
Balance of theoretical research and practical engineering

context.approach: Skyler's education at Princeton combines rigorous technical training with hands-on project work and research. He actively seeks opportunities to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems, whether through climate research at HMEI, robotics projects at the Robotics Club, or independent ventures. His interdisciplinary interests—spanning AI, robotics, climate science, and finance—reflect a curiosity-driven approach to learning and problem-solving.
context.philosophy: Views education not just as knowledge acquisition but as skill-building through doing. Believes the best way to learn is to build, and actively engages in projects that push technical boundaries while addressing meaningful problems.
